name: Cronos

hoverInfo.quick: King of the Titans who ruled during the Golden Age. Father of Zeus, whom he swallowed to prevent a prophecy.

sections.content: Cronos (also spelled Kronos or Cronus) was the King of the Titans and ruler of the cosmos during the mythological Golden Age. The youngest and most ambitious of the primordial Titans, he overthrew his father Uranus with a sickle and ruled the universe until he was in turn overthrown by his own son Zeus. His fear of a prophecy that his children would usurp him led to his infamous act of swallowing each child at birth, an act that ultimately sealed his fate.
sections.title: Description

sections.content: Cronos was the youngest of the twelve Titans, children of Uranus (Sky) and Gaia (Earth). When Uranus imprisoned some of his monstrous offspring in Tartarus, Gaia gave Cronos an adamantine sickle and encouraged him to castrate his father. Cronos ambushed Uranus, severed his genitals, and cast them into the sea (from which Aphrodite was born from the foam). From the blood that fell on earth sprang the Giants, the Erinyes (Furies), and the Meliae (ash tree nymphs).
sections.title: The Castration of Uranus

sections.content: Having heard a prophecy that he would be overthrown by his own child, Cronos swallowed each of his children immediately after Rhea bore them: Hestia, Demeter, Hera, Hades, and Poseidon. When Zeus was born, Rhea hid him in a cave on Crete and gave Cronos a stone wrapped in swaddling clothes, which he swallowed thinking it was the infant. Zeus grew to manhood in secret, then returned to force Cronos to disgorge his siblings, leading to the Titanomachy - the great war between the Titans and Olympians.
sections.title: The Swallowing of the Children

mythsAndLegends.title: The Castration of Uranus
mythsAndLegends.summary: Gaia, suffering from Uranus's cruelty in imprisoning their monstrous children in Tartarus, gave Cronos an adamantine sickle. When Uranus came to lie with Gaia, Cronos ambushed him and castrated him, throwing the severed genitals into the sea. From the foam arose Aphrodite; from the blood that fell on earth came the Giants, the Furies, and the Meliae.

mythsAndLegends.title: The Swallowing of the Children
mythsAndLegends.summary: Warned by a prophecy that his own child would overthrow him, Cronos swallowed each of his children immediately after their birth - Hestia, Demeter, Hera, Hades, and Poseidon. When Zeus was born, Rhea tricked Cronos by giving him a stone wrapped in swaddling clothes while hiding the infant in a cave on Crete.

mythsAndLegends.title: The Titanomachy
mythsAndLegends.summary: Zeus, grown to manhood, gave Cronos a potion that made him disgorge his siblings. The freed gods, led by Zeus, waged a ten-year war against Cronos and the Titans. The Olympians, aided by the Cyclopes and Hundred-Handed Ones whom they freed from Tartarus, ultimately defeated the Titans and cast them into Tartarus.

mythsAndLegends.title: The Golden Age
mythsAndLegends.summary: Despite his dark deeds, Cronos's reign was remembered as the Golden Age - a time of peace, prosperity, and harmony when humans lived like gods, free from toil and suffering. The earth gave forth its bounty freely, and death came like gentle sleep. This nostalgic myth represents humanity's longing for a lost paradise.

mythsAndLegends.title: Ruler of Elysium
mythsAndLegends.summary: Some traditions held that Zeus eventually freed Cronos from Tartarus and made him ruler of the Elysian Fields (the Islands of the Blessed), where he presided over the honored dead. This represents a reconciliation between generations and the possibility of redemption.

description: Cronos (Kronos) was the King of the Titans and ruler of the cosmos during the mythological Golden Age. The youngest of the primordial Titans, he overthrew his father Uranus with an adamantine sickle provided by Gaia, and ruled until his own son Zeus led an uprising that ended in the Titanomachy. His fear of a prophecy - that his children would overthrow him as he had overthrown Uranus - led him to swallow each child at birth, but this act ultimately sealed his fate. Though often conflated with Chronos (the personification of Time), Cronos was originally a harvest deity whose name may derive from a word meaning 'to cut' or 'to reap.'
summary: Cronos was the King of the Titans who overthrew his father Uranus and ruled during the Golden Age. His fear of a prophecy led him to swallow his children, but Zeus escaped, freed his siblings, and led them to victory in the Titanomachy. Though originally a harvest deity, Cronos became associated with time through conflation with Chronos.

symbolism.sickle: The weapon of generational overthrow, representing both harvest and violent succession
symbolism.time: Through conflation with Chronos, represents time's inexorable passage and its consumption of all things
symbolism.swallowing: Fear of being replaced, resistance to change, and the futility of fighting fate
symbolism.golden_age: Nostalgia for a lost paradise, humanity's longing for innocence and abundance

attributes.realm: Mount Othrys (during his reign), later Tartarus, then Elysium
